analytic.title: Knowledge-Based Systems

biblStruct.note: Received 27 January 2015 Revised 5 October 2015 Accepted 6 October 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Concept lattice Approximate concept construction Three-way decisions Attribute reduction Attribute characteristic

div.p: Incomplete contexts are a kind of formal contexts in which the relationship between some objects and some attributes is unavailable or lost. Knowledge discovery in incomplete contexts is of interest because such databases are frequently encountered in the real world. This paper mainly focuses on two issues: approximate concept construction with three-way decisions and attribute reduction in incomplete contexts. The theory of three-way decisions is formulated based on the notions of acceptance, rejection and non-commitment. It is an extension of the commonly used binary-decision model with an added third option. Based on three-way decisions, we propose two models to construct approximate concepts in incomplete contexts, and the equivalence of the two is revealed. To simplify the representation of the approximate concept lattices, we further present the attribute reduction approaches.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The theory of formal concept analysis (FCA), proposed by Wille [14,63], is a mathematical tool for conceptual data analysis and knowledge processing. It mainly concerns the lattice structure, called a concept lattice, constructed by the formal concepts embedded in a concept hierarchy. A formal concept, is a pair consisting of a set of objects (the extension), which includes all objects belonging to the concept, and a set of attributes (the intension), which includes all the attributes common to objects in the extension. In the last two decades, FCA has been successfully applied to information retrieval, knowledge discovery, data mining, machine learning, software engineering, etc. [2,4,6,10,13,24,25,[46][47][48]56,57].

As is well known, knowledge reduction is a key issue in rough set theory [45], and the main objective is to simplify the representation of knowledge so as to gain optimized decision rules. Recently a large number of reduction methods have been developed for different types of information systems and decision tables [8,19,22,42,51,62,67]. Similarly, knowledge reduction in FCA has also received much attention in the past decades [5,9,14,16,26]. Specially, much attention has been paid to attribute reduction of formal contexts in FCA. For example, Ganter and Wille [14] proposed to reduce the context by removing both the reducible attributes and objects.

The concept lattice obtained from the reduced context is isomorphic to the one induced from the original context. Zhang et al. [77] presented an approach to attribute reduction by keeping all the extensions unchanged. Wang and Zhang [60], Li et al. [34] conducted attribute reduction based on irreducible elements respectively, which are equivalent to Zhang et al.'s method without generating all the concepts. Wu et al. [65] removed redundant attributes to keep information granule, i.e., all extensions of the object concepts, unchanged. Shao and Leung [53] revealed that granular reducts obtained by Wu et al.'s approach [65] are equivalent to dominance reducts. Some researchers focus on the issue of attribute reduction from other perspectives instead of classical FCA. For example, Liu et al. [39] conducted attribute reduction in rough set-based concept lattice [12,68], Li and Wu [35] reduced attributes from the perspective of covering rough set, Mi et al. [41] gave the approaches to attribute reduction in concept lattices induced by axialities. Besides, some attribute reduction approaches in decision formal context [61] are proposed based on rule acquisition [29,30,33,54].

There is an underlying assumption in classical concept lattice and the extended versions: the binary relation in the formal context is definite, and either the object x has the attribute a, or the opposite holds. In many real-world situations, however, it may happen that the relationship between some objects and some attributes is unavailable or lost, and there may be a third relation between the object and the attribute. In this case, the contexts are called incomplete contexts [3]. (And the classical formal contexts are called complete ones.)

Recently, there is a growing interest in the study of the incomplete contexts [3,11,18,23,31,44]. However, most of the research focuses on attribute implication or attribute exploration, and few efforts have been devoted to concept construction in incomplete contexts. Although Li et al. [31] have given an approximate concept construction approach by representing each concept intension as a pair (definite common attributes, possible common attributes), they only take the positive information, i.e., the common (or possible common) attributes shared by the extension, into consideration. Nevertheless, in some cases, some negative information is of equal importance. For example, when a patient chooses some Over-The-Counter (OTC) medicines for a special disease, he must pay attention to the indications (the positive information) and the contraindications (the negative information) of the medicines. In this case, the objects are the OTC medicines, and the attributes are diseases. The indications, the contraindications, and other diseases that are not listed in the medicines' instruction form a tripartition of the attribute set, which falls into the category of three-way decisions.

The theory of three-way decisions, proposed by Yao [73], is an extension of the commonly used acceptance-rejection binary model with an added third option: non-commitment [70][71][72][73][74]. The basic ideas in the theory of three-way decisions are based on a tripartition of a universal set. A tripartition consists of three pair-wise disjoint subsets, namely the positive region POS, the negative region NEG and the boundary region BND, of the universe set [73]. Corresponding to the three regions, one can construct rules for acceptance, rejection and non-commitment, respectively [70,71]. Three-way decisions play a key role in everyday decision-making and have been widely used in many fields and disciplines [1,17,20,21,28,32,[36][37][38]40,58,66,[74][75][76]78].

In fact, some researchers have introduced the theory of three-way decisions into FCA in complete contexts. For example, Ganter and Kuznetsov [15] pointed out that the version space is by definition the set of classifiers that match all positive examples and do not match any negative examples. Rodriguez-Jimenez et al. proposed the mixed formal concept lattice, in which both positive and negative attributes are contained, to extract mix rules [52]. Qi et al. proposed two threeway formal concept lattices, namely the OE-concept lattice and the AE-concept lattice [49].

Motivated by the works mentioned above, this paper focuses on approximate concept construction with three-way decisions and attribute reduction in incomplete contexts. Compared with other methods, for example [31], that deal with missing information, the advantage of using three-way decisions is that it deals with the missing information from two aspects simultaneously, the positive aspect and the negative aspect.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 briefly reviews some basic notions related to complete contexts and incomplete contexts. Section 3 proposes two models to construct three-way approximate concepts in incomplete contexts, and then the equivalence of the two models is proved. After that, Section 4 discusses attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in the three-way approximate concept lattices. Finally, Section 5 concludes this paper.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: In this section, we briefly review some basic notions related to complete contexts, and then introduce the notion of incomplete context. A formal context can be represented by a two-dimensional table filled with, e.g., plus and minus signs, where a "+ in row x and column a indicates that the object x has the attribute a, and a "in-

Definition 2 ([14]). For a set of objects X⊆U, and a set of attributes B⊆A, the derivation operators are given by

X * is the maximal subset of attributes common to the objects in X, and B * is the maximal subset of objects that possess all the attributes in B. For x ∈ U and a ∈ A, we write x * and a * instead of {x} * and {a} * .

The derivation operators are also called positive operators in [49]. They are two-way operators due to the fact that for each X ⊆ U, X * and A -X * form a bipartition of A (though one of the two regions may be empty, the family of the two regions is still called a bipartition), and likewise, B * and U -B * form a bipartition of U [49]. The information obtained by the positive operators is called positive information.

Following the standard notations in FCA [14], when depicting formal concepts, sets are separator-free if without confusion, e.g., 234 stands for {2, 3, 4}.

div.head: Definition 4 ([3]
div.p: ). An incomplete context is a quadruple IC = (U, A, {+, ?, -}, T ), where U and A are sets of objects and attributes respectively, {+, ?, -} is the set of values, and T ⊆ U × A × {+, ?, -} is a ternary relation such that (x, a, +) ∈ T means the object x has the attribute a, (x, a, -) ∈ T means the object x does not have the attribute a, (x, a, ?) ∈ T indicates we do not know whether the object x has the attribute a.

To distinguish a formal context (Definition 1) from an incomplete context, the former is called a complete context. In this paper, complete contexts are considered as a special kind of incomplete contexts. This is reasonable because a complete context (U, A, R) can be denoted as (U, A, {+, ?, -}, T ), and (x, a, +) ∈ T holds in the latter iff (x, a) ∈ R holds in the former, and (x, a, -) ∈ T iff (x, a) ∈ R.
An incomplete context IC = (U, A, {+, ?, -}, T ) is called regular if T satisfies the following conditions:
(1) ∀ x ∈ U, ∃ a, b ∈ A, such that (x, a, +) ∈ T, and (x, b, -) ∈ T, (2) ∀ a ∈ A, ∃ x, y ∈ U, such that (x, a, +) ∈ T, and (y, a, -) ∈ T.
In this paper, we assume that all incomplete contexts are regular before attribute reduction.

The question mark in row 2 and column a indicates that the relationship between the object 2 and the attributes a is unknown, and the other question marks can be explained in a similar way.

div.head: Approximate concept construction with three-way decisions in incomplete contexts
div.p: Just as mentioned in the introduction, the positive information (obtained by the positive operators) is as important as the negative information (obtained by the negative operators) to describe a concept. To achieve this goal, in this section, we propose two models based on three-way decisions to construct the approximate concept lattice of an incomplete context, one is based on three-way approximate operators, and the other is based on the tripartition of the ternary relation.

Remark 2. When the context is complete, the OE-approximate concept lattice is the OE-concept lattice, and the AE-approximate concept lattice is the AE-concept lattice given by Qi et al. [49]. Most recently, Qi et al. further studied the connections between the three-way concept lattices of a complete context and the classical lattices induced by the positive and the negative operators (defined by Eqs. 2.1, 2.2, and 2.6, and 2.7) in [50]. And we will reveal the connections between the three-way approximate concept lattices of an incomplete context and the classical lattices in Section 3.3.

Since the OE-approximate concept lattice and the AE-approximate concept lattice follow the theoretical framework of classical concept lattice, any existing algorithm such as those in [27] can be adopted to construct them. Here Norris' algorithm [43] was adapted and the adapted version is named Norris_OE (Norris_AE, resp.), which can be used to build the OE-approximate concept lattice (the AEapproximate concept lattice, resp.) of an incomplete context. Both the OE-virtual and the AE-virtual complete context of IC approximately represent the original information of IC by the positive and the negative region of the ternary relation T. In some sense, they can be considered as approximate contexts of IC. Accordingly, each formal concept in L(C VO ) or L(C VA ) contains both the positive and the negative information of IC, and they can be considered as approximate concepts of IC.

div.head: Relationship between the two approximate concept construction models
div.p: In this subsection, we investigate the relationship of the two approximate concept construction models proposed in Sections 3.1 and 3.2.

div.p: Proof. It is similar to the proof of Theorem 1.
By Theorems 1 and 2, the equivalence of the two approximate concept construction models using three-way decisions is revealed, which lays a foundation for the study in Section 4.

div.head: Attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in three-way approximate concept lattices
div.p: In this section, we mainly focus on the issues of attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in three-way approximate concept lattices. First, we recall some basic notions and existing approaches to the two issues related to the classical concept lattice.

div.head: Attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in the concept lattice of a complete context
div.p: Zhang et al. proposed an approach to attribute reduction in the classical concept lattice of a complete context [77] based on discernibility matrix and discernibility function. This method gives us an insight into the nature of the reduct: a reduct is a minimal subset of attributes that can discern each pair of the concepts, which results in the structure of the lattice unchanged. Besides, it provides us with a sufficient and necessary condition for the reduct, and with this method we can get all the attribute reducts.

div.head: Definition 14 ([77]). Let
div.formula: C i = (U, A i , R i ) (i = 1, 2) be two complete contexts, and L(C i ) be their concept lattices. If for any (X 2 , B 2 ) ∈ L(C 2 ), there exists (X 1 , B 1 ) ∈ L(C 1 ), such that X 1 = X 2 , then L(C 1 ) is said to be finer than L(C 2 ), which is denoted by L(C 1 ) ≤ L(C 2 ). If L(C 1 ) ≤ L(C 2 ) and L(C 2 ) ≤ L(C 1 )
div.p: , then the two concept lattices are isomorphism to each other, and denoted by L(C 2 ) ∼ = L(C 1 ). There may be more than one reduct for C. All the reducts can be obtained based on the discernibility matrix. D⊆A is a reduct of C iff ∧D is a prime implicant of the discernibility function f( ) [77].
div.formula: Let C = (U, A, R), R D = R ∩ (U × D),

div.head: Definition 16 ([77]). The discernibility attribute set between two concepts
div.formula: C i = (X i , B i ) and C j = (X j , B j ) of a complete context C is de- fined as DIS(C i , C j ) = (B i ∪ B j -B i ∩ B j ).
div.p: After all the reducts of a complete context are obtained, the attributes can be classified into three types. Definition 18 ([77]). Let D i (i ∈ τ , τ is an index set) be all the reducts of C. Then the attribute set A can be divided into three parts: (1). the set of absolutely necessary attributes/the core: Core = i∈τ D i , (2). the set of relatively necessary attributes: RN = i∈τ D i -i∈τ D i , (3). the set of absolutely unnecessary attributes: AU = A -i∈τ D i .

The characteristics of these types of attributes can be analyzed based on ∧-irreducible elements [59,60], from which all the reducts can be acquired in another way. Definition 19 ([7]). Let L be a lattice. a ∈ L is called a ∧-irreducible element, if a = 1 (in case L has an identity element), and
div.formula: a = b ∧ c implies a = b or a = c (b, c ∈ L).
div.p: In a concept lattice, the ∧-irreducible element must be an attribute concept, i.e., it is in the form of (a * , a * * ), where a ∈ A. However, the converse does not hold.

div.head: Lemma 3 ([59,60]). Let C = (U, A, R) be a complete context. For any a
div.formula: ∈ A, (a * , a * * ) is ∧-irreducible iff {b ∈ A|a * ⊂ b * } = ∅ or a * ⊂ {b * |a * ⊂ b * }(⇔ {b ∈ A|a * ⊂ b * } * = a * [34] ). Lemma 4 ([59,60]). Let C = (U, A, R) be a complete context, a ∈ A, then (1) a ∈ Core iff (a * , a * * ) is ∧-irreducible, and ∀b ∈ A -{a}, a * = b * ; (2) a ∈ RN iff (a * , a * * ) is ∧-irreducible, and ∃b ∈ A -{a}, a * = b * ; (3) a ∈ AU iff (a * , a * * ) is not ∧-irreducible.
div.p: Based on Lemma 4, all the reducts of a complete context can be obtained in another way.

div.head: Theorem 3 ([59]). Let C be a complete context, IND
div.formula: = {(a, b) ∈ RN × RN|a * = b * }, [a] IND = {b ∈ RN|(a, b) ∈ IND}.D⊆A is a reduct of C iff D = Core ∪ {a 1 , a 2 , • • • , a t }, where t i=1 [a i ] IND = RN, and if i = j with 1 ≤ i, j ≤ t, [a i ] IND ∩ [a j ] IND = ∅. Corollary 1. Let C be a complete context, Irr = Core ∪ RN,IND = {(a, b) ∈ Irr × Irr|a * = b * }, [a] IND = {b ∈ Irr|(a, b) ∈ IND}.D is a reduct iff D = {a 1 , a 2 , • • • , a s }, where s i=1 [a i ] IND = Irr, and if i = j with 1 ≤ i, j ≤ s, [a i ] IND ∩ [a j ] IND = ∅.
div.p: Proof. It follows from Theorem 3 and Lemma 4.

Since the concept lattices L(C VO ) and L(C VA ) are the classical concept lattices of complete contexts, attribute reducts and attribute characteristics in them can be obtained by the approaches mentioned above. In this paper, we only focus on the issues of attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in the OE-approximate concept lattice and the AE-approximate concept lattice of an incomplete context.

div.head: Attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in OE-approximate concept lattice
div.p: In this subsection, we mainly study the issue of attribute reduction in the OE-approximate concept lattice induced from an incomplete context. First, we introduce the notion of OE-reduct. Definition 20. Let IC i = (U, A i , {+, ?, -}, T i ) (i = 1, 2) be two incomplete contexts, and OEL(IC i ) be their OE-approximate concept lattices. If ∀(X 2 , (B 2 , C 2 )) ∈ OEL(IC 2 ), there exists (X 1 , (B 1 , C 1 )) ∈ OEL(IC 1 ), such that X 1 = X 2 , then OEL(IC 1 ) is said to be finer than OEL(IC 2 ), which is denoted by OEL(IC 1 ) ≤ OEL(IC 2 ).

If OEL(IC 1 ) ≤ OEL(IC 2 ) and OEL(IC 2 ) ≤ OEL(IC 1 ), then they are isomorphism to each other and denoted by OEL(IC 1 ) ∼ = OEL(IC 2 ). Definition 22. The discernibility attribute set pair between two OEapproximate concepts OC i = (X i , (B i , C i )) and OC j = (X j , (B j , C j )) of an incomplete context IC is defined as

div.p: And the OE-discernibility matrix of IC is defined as
div.formula: OE = DIS OE (OC i , OC j )|OC i , OC j ∈ OEL(IC) . (4.5)

div.head: Judgement theorems of OE-consistent set
div.p: In this section, we focus on the conditions on which a subset D of attributes is an OE-reduct of IC. As we have known, D⊆A is an OEreduct of IC if and only if D is an OE-consistent set of IC, and ∀d ∈ D, D -{d} is not an OE-consistent set of IC. So we only need to find the conditions on which D is an OE-consistent set.

div.head: Theorem 4. D is an OE-consistent set of an incomplete context IC iff OEL(IC D ) ≤ OEL(IC).
Proof. D is an OE-consistent set of IC ⇔ OEL(IC D ) ∼ = OEL(IC) ⇔ OEL(IC D ) ≤ OEL(IC) and OEL(IC) ≤ OEL(IC D ).

Theorem 5 gives several direct methods to get OE-consistent sets. Besides, considering the equivalent relationship between the OEapproximate concept lattice of an incomplete context IC and the concept lattice of the AE-virtual complete context C VA (Theorem 1), we get an indirect approach to obtain the OE-consistent sets. Theorem 6. Let IC be an incomplete context, and
div.formula: C VA = (U, A ∪ A, R VA ) be the AE-virtual complete context. If D ⊆ A ∪ A is a consistent set of C VA , then D 1 = (D ∩ A) ∪ {a ∈ A|a ∈ D ∩ A} is an OE-consistent set. Proof. Obviously, D 1 ∪ D 1 ⊇ D is a consistent set of C VA . From Definition 17 we get L(C VA ) ∼ = L(C VA D 1 ), where C VA D 1 = (U, D 1 ∪ D 1 , R VA ∩ (U × (D 1 ∪ D 1 ))). On the other hand, from Theorem 1, we have L(C VA ) ∼ = OEL(IC) and L(C VA D 1 ) ∼ = OEL(IC D 1 ), therefore, OEL(IC) ∼ = OEL(IC D 1 ), which implies that D 1 is an OE-consistent set of IC.
div.p: Based on the judgement theorems for OE-consistent sets, we give the judgement theorem of OE-reducts.
div.formula: Theorem 7. Let IC be an incomplete context, D⊆A, D = ∅, E = A -D.
div.p: Then, D is an OE-reduct iff the following properties hold
div.formula: (1) D is an OE-consistent set; (2) ∀d ∈ D, either ((d, ∅) -(E, E)) = ((d, ∅) ∩ (D, D)) = (d, ∅) or ((∅, d) -(E, E)) = ((∅, d) ∩ (D, D)) = (∅, d) holds.

div.p: For each attribute a ∈ A, we can generate two OE-approximate concepts con(a, ∅) and con(∅, a) simultaneously. From Example 7, we observe that for the attribute a, con(a, ∅) is a ∧-irreducible element and con(∅, a) is a ∧-reducible element, while for the attribute c, both con(c, ∅) and con(∅, c) are ∧-irreducible. To make a distinction between the two types of attributes, we introduce the notions of weak and strong irreducible attribute.

div.head: Definition 24.
div.p: Let IC be an incomplete context. An attribute a is weak irreducible if either con(a, ∅) or con(∅, a) is a ∧-irreducible element in OEL(IC). a is strong irreducible if both con(a, ∅) and con(∅, a) are ∧-irreducible elements.

The set of all weak irreducible attributes is denoted as WI. The set of all strong irreducible attributes is denoted as SI. Apparently, SI⊆WI. Based on Theorem 9, we can obtain all the weak and the strong irreducible attributes of an incomplete context. Example 8. For the incomplete context IC shown in Table 2, the set of all weak ∧-irreducible elements in OEL(IC) (shown in Fig. 2) is {a, b, c, d, e, h}, and the set of all strong ∧-irreducible elements is {c, d}. div.head: B. Attribute characteristics of incomplete contexts
div.p: Next we will investigate the attribute characteristics in an incomplete context with respect to the OE-approximate concept lattice. Similar to the case in a complete context, we can get the necessary and the sufficient condition for the core attributes (Theorem 11). Compared with the characteristics of the relatively necessary attributes and the absolutely unnecessary attributes in a complete context with respect to the OE-approximate concept lattice, their counterparts in an incomplete context are much more difficult to check, since only the necessary condition for the relatively necessary attributes holds (Theorem 12), and only the sufficient condition for the absolutely unnecessary attributes holds (Theorem 13).

div.head: Attribute reduction and attribute characteristics in AE-approximate concept lattice
div.p: In this subsection, we mainly study the issue of attribute reduction in AE-approximate concept lattice of an incomplete context. First, we introduce the notion of AE-reduct.

div.head: Definition 25.
div.p: Let IC i = (U, A i , {+, ?, -}, T i ) (i = 1, 2) be two incomplete contexts, and AEL(IC i ) be their AE-approximate concept lattices respectively. If ∀((X 2 , Y 2 ), B 2 ) ∈ AEL(IC 2 ), there exists ((X 1 , Y 1 ), B 1 ) ∈ AEL(IC 1 ), such that (X 1 , Y 1 ) = (X 2 , Y 2 ), then AEL(IC 1 ) is said to be finer than AEL(IC 2 ), which is denoted by AEL(IC 1 ) ≤ AEL(IC 2 ).

If AEL(IC 1 ) ≤ AEL(IC 2 ) and AEL(IC 2 ) ≤ AEL(IC 1 ), then they are isomorphism to each other and denoted by AEL(IC 1 ) ∼ = AEL(IC 2 ). The attribute reduction approach in AE-approximate concept lattice is similar to that in the classical concept lattice of a complete context proposed by Zhang et al. [77], so it is omitted in this paper.

Here we give another method to get the AE-reducts of an incomplete context. Theorem 15 shows the equivalence between the reducts of the OEvirtual complete context and the AE-reducts of an incomplete context. This gives us an indirect way to obtain all the AE-reducts.

The judgement methods of the attribute characteristics with respect to the AE-approximate concept lattice of an incomplete context are similar to Lemmas 3 and 4. (2) a is a relatively necessary attribute iff (a , a ) is ∧-irreducible, and ∃b ∈ A -{a}, a = b ;

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, we proposed two models to construct approximate concept with three-way decisions in incomplete contexts. One is from the perspective of the three-way approximate operators, and the other is from perspective of the tripartition of the ternary relation of the incomplete context. In each model, the approximate concepts contains both the positive and the negative information simultaneously. It has been proved that the two models are equivalent to each other. After the approximate concept lattices were constructed, attribute reduction approaches were given based on discernibility function in incomplete contexts, which simplify the representation of the approximate concepts. And attribute characteristics were analyzed based on irreducible elements, which provide us with another way to obtain the reducts without generating all the approximate concepts.

For an object x and an attribute a, (x, a) ∈ R indicates the object x has the attribute a, and (x, a) ∈ R indicates the opposite.
